body.p: In the population, 8% of males have had a kidney stone. Suppose a medical researcher randomly selects two males from a large population.
Let A represent the event "the first male has had a kidney stone."
Let B represent the event "the second male has had a kidney stone."
True or false? A and B are independent events.

response.feedback: Correct. The occurrence of A does not affect the probability of B since the men are randomly selected from a large population. So the events are independent.
Incorrect. In this problem the events are independent since the men are randomly selected from a large population, so the occurrence of A does not affect the probability of B.

body.p: In 2012, researchers working with a very large population of health records found that 9.3% of all Americans had diabetes (source: National Diabetes Statistics Report, 2014). Suppose a medical researcher randomly selects two individuals from a large population.
Let A represent the event “the first individual has diabetes.”
Let B represent the event “the second individual has diabetes.”
True or false? A and B are independent events.

response.feedback: Correct. The occurrence of A does not affect the probability of B since the two individuals are randomly selected from a large population. So the events are independent.
Incorrect. In this problem the events are independent since the individuals are randomly selected from a large population, so the occurrence of A does not affect the probability of B.
